CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrew Perez is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents today with an upper respiratory infection, as well as symptoms of fatigue and shortness of breath. He reports working out in the yard in the last week. He started to feel really tired, was short of breath and surprised by the symptoms. He believes he caught his first cold. He denies any seasonal allergies. The patient has had his covid vaccine and denies any respiratory ailments. He has been taking his lisinopril 20 mg daily. He states he has been watching his diet and sugar intake while he is going to work during the week, but not so much if it is a Saturday or Sunday. His diet has been good for the most part, except for house parties and things like that. He is not doing well with his medications. He notes that his wife got him into barre classes to help him relax and he thinks it is working. He ended up with some tension around his knees, but he thought that was a lot of do with lifting the bags.
 
The patient denies fever, chills, muscle aches, joint pain, fatigue, and any recent changes in his physical appearance. Mr. Perez does acknowledge some edema of the lower extremities and pain to palpation of his elbows bilaterally. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses dyspnea on exertion.
 • Neurological/Psychological: Endorse fatigue and edema in the bilateral upper extremities.
ⓘPHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally with no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
­ Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
· Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal, he means he is doing well on metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

ℂ The patient is status post covid-19 and has not had any episodes of respiratory distress since that time.

 │ Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to utilize alternative medications for his depression. We discussed the importance of coping mechanisms and I encouraged him to utilize barre class for relaxation.
 - Additional Testing: We will order a covid test for further evaluation.
 ├── Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms are consistent with a viral syndrome. He does not appear to be suffering from any other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. His blood pressure has been elevated at last glance, but has not been elevated since this episode of his illness.
 | Medical Treatment : We will increase Metformin to 1000 mg once daily, and order a hemoglobin a1c in 4 months.

She has not had any joint pain recently. The patient endorsed joint congestion due to her allergies. She continues to take methotrexate 2.5 mg once weekly. If she needs a refill, she will contact me at the clinic if she has any issues with the medication. Regarding her asthma, she has tried meditation, trying running with her dog to try and relieve her stress, but it has not really been working. She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, or vomiting.

Mr. Albert Perry is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant, who is here today for emergency room follow up. He was notified by the nurse that he was in the emergency room for elevated blood sugar. The patient admits to not staying on top of his blood sugar readings over the weekend. He felt a little concerned and asked his wife to take him in. His blood sugar was elevated and he was admitted to the hospital. He denies any symptoms of lightheadedness, dizziness, or chest pain. He does note that his lungs are clear to auscultation 1+ in the bilateral lower extremities. The pulmonary embolism was briefly noted but resolved after the patient was checked in. He notes that he has been following his diet very well during the week but is not consistent with his diet on the weekends. By the end of the visit today, he wants to contact me if he has any questions or needs help. 

The patient’s last time he saw Dr. Reyes, he saw him about 3 weeks ago, and everything seemed to be fine. He remembers that his mother had a hip replacement and is feeling better. He reports that she has been grabbing meals at the cafeteria or picking up fast food on her way home. He adds that he had been compliant with his medications and following doctor's orders. The man denies any carotid bruits.
 
He notes that his wife has been into meditation recently, and he finds that relaxing. He has continued to benefit from this.
 The patient denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, or pain.

 2nd problem: Kidney transplant. His kidneys seem to be doing well postoperatively. After reviewing his physical exam today, I do not believe this will be an issue for the near future.

Ms. James is a pleasant 57-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder and elbow pain. He fell 5 months ago going up stairs and the pain has been present since. He states he stepped on an icy surface and fell on his left side. He notes that his shoulder and wrist took the brunt. The patient reports that he has been hitting the gym and lifting weights 2 days per week for the past 2 weeks. The pain is worse when he lifts. He has also been unable to lift more than 15 to 20 pounds. He denies any numbness or tingling. At this point, he has tried iced and iced not too much, but he denies taking any medication for pain. His symptoms improve when he walks about 30 minutes daily. He does keep up with his walking since he retired from his office job last year. Mr. James endorses that he really enjoys his exercise, but over the past 1st of 2 weeks he has cut back on his gym time as the pain is not worth it. He recommends that the patient continue to ice, especially his left shoulder. I recommend that he also continue to use ice on his elbow and left wrist. 
Of note, he reports that calling the clinic if his symptoms worsen or his pain improves has been helpful.
 
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Mr. James is a new patient who presents today for further evaluation. His pain is constant. He reports constant left arm pain.
• Neurological: Endorses numbness in left wrist and shoulder. Patient reports erythema and deformity in right shoulder.
Skin: Positive hawkins-kennedy and neer's test. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Independent median radial ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees. Normal empty tan test.
Neurological: W-what i think you are dealing with is impingement syndrome of your left shoulder, elbow and wrist. I do not think there is an additional injury or issue with your wrist, but because everything is connected, you're experiencing pain in your left wrist because of your shoulder. We do see this type of issue when someone has a fall, so it is good that they came in to see us so we could help.
­INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me within the next day or two to get his appointment scheduled.

Randy Gutierrez is a pleasant 2-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of runny nose and cradle cap.

The patient has been experiencing intermittent runny noses and congestion for the past 10 days. His symptoms started last night after supper time. He was warm when he took his sleeper off of him and we had the ac on in the house. He states that he was sweating. He denies any fever. The patient reports that he has been pulling on his ears and has a cough that is not barky. He has been using the cradle cap brush and regular aveno shampoo. Not sure if he is using dandruff shampoo or honey nut cheerios. Initially, he was irritable, but now he seems energetic and wants to take more naps. Currently, he is energetic but stops taking naps at night. He seems to be irritable because he is not feeling good. He is going to try Zarbee's today, which is a different type of nectar. If he continues to have congestion, we will give him half a teaspoon of sister's medicine, which would be half the dose for 5 days. He should follow up with me as needed if his symptoms get worse. I will post his appointment and all of his results will be in the clinic.
=-=-REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses congestion.
Skin: Examination of the newborn baby’s ears reveals mild congestion and some mildr symptoms of cradle cap, which should resolve with use of anti-inflammatory and regular strength shampoos. Shampoos 2-3 times per week, not every day, but maybe twice per week.
- Auscultation of Lungs: Bilateral bilateral lumbar hematochezia, or “cubary cap”
• Examination of Abdomen: Normal strength pillow, no extra strength required.
 – Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue to use the soft brush and baby oil, which will help to get the scales out. I advised him to use regular strength humidifier, 2 days between shampooing, and then use the shampoo normally. Within 6 weeks, you will notice that the-the cradle cap has resolved and that he no longer has it. I recommended that we treat the patient as-is. We will see him back in one week for further evaluation.

Acne.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Kayla Ward is a 7th grade female who presents for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face. The acne started approximately 2 years ago and is present most every day. She has been using persa-gel and washing regularly, which is somewhat helpful. There are no associated symptoms including itching, bleeding, or pain. She lives with her parents and sister. They have a dog, bird, and bunny. She is in7th grade. She plays basketball and volleyball and tap. She wears sunscreen in the summer. She denies any family history. The biggest flare, probably, was when she started school sports in the fall. She reports that her acne flares with her periods. She thinks about 2 years has elapsed since her last period.
Mrs. Ward has been doing a good job with facial care regimen, but it does not seem to help as much as we wanted. We discussed topical therapy and using an Elf facial cleanser and noncomedogenic moisturizer. She endorses using water and a washcloth in the morning, and if she feels greasy in the evening, she will use a moisturizer with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher. This means it will clog her pores. She will start using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night. If it is not covered by insurance, she can try different gel over the counter.
 She also has multiple benign moles on her arms, legs, and back. The chest and back are relatively spared. I want to highlight the multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities. She scattered skin colored papules over the face, primarily on the forehead and with some on the central cheeks and chin. Normal exam is performed today. If she has any progress over the next 6 months, we will follow up at that time.

Ms. Julia Jones is a 25-year-old female with symptomatic macromastia, presenting for evaluation of breast reduction. The patient has attempted nonsurgical treatments, but the minimal relief. She is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty. Her minimum required resection, based on a BSA of 2.65 with the Schnur scale is 1,792 grams, which should be attainable. Given her extremely large breasts and the measurements above, there is potential for using a nipple graft. She has been going to a chiropractor for a few years, and reports experiencing back pain and swelling in her neck and upper back that she does not know if it is due to her breasts or not. The pain improves when she is working at her desk all day. She denies any rashes associated with breast tenderness or tingling. Regarding nipple pain, she notes that sometimes she has pain with working out and any jumping or running. She treats physical therapy for her back pain. Psychiatric
The patient denies any history of breast cancer. Her mother was 40 when she had her last mammogram, but her mother has since died. She plans to have the procedure in July as she is likely to be transferred to a new plan. She will follow up with the insurance company once she has all the paperwork submitted.

Ms. Wood is an established patient who presents for renal ultrasound because of hematuria.

Urine dipstick today: Negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketone, bilirubin, and glucose. The urine is yellow and clear, urobilinogen 0.2,5, and specific gravity 1.020. There is a trace amount of blood in the urine and intact. She reports that she has had several episodes of bright red urine for the past 6 weeks. The most recent episode was due to kidney stones. She passed 2 small stones last week. She knew it was a kidney stone when she scheduled this appointment and immediately felt pain when she urinated. For the past week, she was constantly having to pee and she rated her pain on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being the worst and 10 being the most painful. She completed the ultrasound and her urostomy cystoma has nearly subsided. She does still have 1 kidney stone in the left kidney, however, it is non-obstructing and not causing pain. At this time, we have not had any flank pain or tenderness in her lower back. She denies any abdominal pain and her back has felt a lot better after passing the stones. 

The patient is only taking alavert 10 mg a day and denies any drug allergies. She estimates that she drinks approximately 125 ounces of water per day. She has a history of kidney stones and notes that she will do whatever it takes to try to avoid getting these stones again. She is provided with a handout with dietary recommendations to avoid food that is salty, processed, or animal protein. Ideally, she should avoid less than 1,000 mg of sodium and reduce the consumption of beef, poultry, fish, and pork.

Ms. Melissa Sanchez is a 62-year-old female who presents for status post cardiac exam of atrial fibrillation and atrial regurgitation. She is being seen in office today for status after her emergency cardiac followup on 9/17. At her previous follow-up, we felt that she was doing quite well from a cardiac standpoint. We recommended she continue to continue using the same medication. The ECG taken on 12/26/2020 reveals atrial feibrillation with controlled ventricular response. T-wave inversion anteriorly. Compared to the previous study, there are no significant changes. Please add in the history, patient has a history of mitral regurggence and Atrial Fibrillation, history of diabetes, asthma, and recurrent chest discomfort. She has been taking her medications regularly. She states that she has been trying to keep up with that. There are a lot of extra pills now, but she does pretty well. She reports that she is learning what she can and can not do. At times, she will have shortness of breath and a shallow breath. She endorses chest pain when exerting herself. The patient notes that this episode usually lasts for a couple of weeks before it resolves. She notes that the atenolol causes her to be irritable in the beginning but she has gotten used to it and does not seem to bother her as much now. We discussed that she will follow up in 6 to 9 months for routine cardio monitoring.

In office today for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis.

Ms. Gomez is doing well and has progressed significantly since her last visit. She is now taking one prednisone dose alone. The patient requested an increase in her dose of methotrexate, which she was told could interfere with the vaccine. She reports that she did not take the second dose of Prednisone until she was in so much pain after she took the first dose. Regarding her bruises, she was asked to explain why she was getting bruises when she bumps herself. She denies any knowledge of the cause.
 The patient inquired about unexplained bruises in her joints, including between her knees. She was advised that the pain is localized to her ankles and also her lower extremities.
Mrs. Gomez mentioned that she has been flexing her toes a lot, which has improved her range of motion. She also noted some ripples in her nails, likely from the psoriasis.
The patient has continued to improve with her physical activity. She estimates that her joint pain was present before she started the metHotrexate but that she is now only experiencing a little pain on days when she is moving around a lot. She recalled that she used to flex her toes occasionally but she had limited availability due to her desk job. Some of the patient's questions included the cause of her bruises and whether or not she is getting bruises.

The pain improves when she walks. She does not have any fevers, chills or shortness of breath. She denies any recent weight gain or changes in her sleep. The patient reports that she has been taking painkillers for her legs, which she does not take every day but when she does feel bad. She states that she gets short of breath if she walks too fast or long. She adds that she sometimes passes out if she tries to overdo it. She has a walker that she uses to get her from driveway to the end of the driveway and the culdesac. She estimates that she may have as much as 70-80% improvement in her symptoms from 6 months ago. Her echocardiogram was ordered and will be completed today. Depending on the severity of her aortic stenosis, we may need to consider an ischemic evaluation or further, possibly a heart mon- monitor to assess overall burden of the PVCS. At this point, she is asymptomatic, so we will start with the echocyardiogram only. Her primary care physician treated her with meclizine today. Due to bilateral leg pain over the last month, she has considered undergoing a chest x-ray and is now going to have one scheduled for evaluation. She is taking all the medicines that were prescribed for her with the exception of her lisinopril. I recommended that the patient discontinue the use of her statin due to her leg pain. She will follow up with me in 3 or 4 weeks to discuss results and next steps.

.- Medical Treatment: Continue with lisinoprinol 25 mg daily. Order for tetanus shot ordered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle Mitchell is a pleasant 67-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right upper lobe lung nodule. The patient was seen by his primary care physician for a cough which initially was diagnosed as bronchitis, but after 3 months the patient was sent to see the PPC for further evaluation and he was told that he did not have pneumonia. He then underwent a chest CT scan which revealed a 2 cm nodule in the lateral aspect of the right lower lobe. The nodule was smooth in appearance and no evidence of emphysematous disease was present. He was then referred to me for evaluation and management as follows:

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Patient reports history of rheumatoid arthritis. He currently takes methotrexate 7.2 mg every week. As long as he is keeping active his joints feel okay, and if he has any problems it is mostly with his hands. He has not had any recent flares.

FAMILY HENCE

Mother, deceased age 60, from complications of breast cancer. Denies any family history of lung cancer or other type of malignancies

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports bilateral pulmonary edema.
Skin: Plight pink to light touch.
Neurological: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No clicks, rubs, or murmurs.
RESPIRATORY: Capillary refill is brisk.
NEURO: Normal respiratory effort.
MSK: Examination of the bilateral upper extremities: No edema to the lower extremities. It looks like you have a little swelling to to your knuckles there on the 3rd digit on each hand. However pulses are intact in all extremities and capillary refill are brisk

RESULTS

Cardiovascular: Blood pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Respiratory rate: 16 bpm
Oxygen saturation: 98%.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient had a Chest CT prior to his arrival today. The results of that CT do reveal a solitary 2 mm nodule on the medial aspect of his right upper lobes. I reviewed the patient's pulmonary function test today and his pulmonary function is normal. I have also ordered a PFT to establish a baseline for his lung function. We will also schedule a PET Ct to determine if the nodule is metabolically active. Given his smoking history and recent flare, I am going to go ahead and suggest that we do remove this during or via video assisted thoracoscopy. I will go in with a camera and scope and we will remove that along with a very small portion of his lung. He will be under general anesthesia and it will take approximately an hour and a half to perform the procedure. After the procedure, he will be admitted and will have a chest tube in until the following day. I advised him that he will most likely be in the hospital for 1 night and will go home the next day.

 RESULTS

X-rays of the bilateral ankle injuries were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal a displaced lateral malleolus at the Weber C level. He will be out for approximately 3 months. We will get him crutches and hopefully he can get back out doing some exercise once he is able to recover.

He has tried Tylenol and Motrin but that has not been helpful. He also tries gabapentin and Tegretol for help. The patient states that he occasionally has headaches but not with any history of migraines. He denies any weakness on his face other than the right side. When the pain comes on, it is like a 10 out of 10 and lasts for awhile. He describes that his smile is equal on both sides of his face. He does not have any sensory loss. Not a hint of numbness or tingling in the right face. Similarly, the patient denies weakness in the left face. They are symmetric and have been in place for 2 months. They states that they have experienced intermittent hot flashes with pain. Occasionally they will also experience memory loss and numbness. Some people can also have a dermatologic skin reaction to this medication, particularly people with Eustachian descent. Unfortunately, this medication is extremely volatile and can cause severe side effects. In regards to his surgical options, he was told that he needs to follow up with me in 1 month if his pain does not improve.

Motor vehicle crashes.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brandon Taylor is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of neck pain. The patient has a history of several car crashes in the past few months. He was fine after his second crash although he was in therapy for a few months and after his third crash he had surgery. He is currently experiencing pain that can be explained by multiple things. His most recent crash was in 02/2021 when he was coming home from a pain clinic because he felt his neck hurt and back hurt. He denies any hematochezia. Unfortunately, the patient has been prescribed fentanyl 15 mg daily for pain and has not filled a prescription for several weeks. He states that he has been avoiding medication that would help with his pain. Currently, he is utilizing Robaxin 15 mg 6-8 hours every 6 to 8 hours. If his pain does not improve, he will discontinue the use of fentanyl and we will refer him to pain management if it becomes complicated. 

The patient denies any fatigue. He reports that his lawyer told him to report to the lawyer due to his neck hurting. I understand that the patient is being provided with the best medical treatment possible. I want to make sure that he is getting the best advise possible.
